so now i'm going to talk about why we decided to go with aws or at least our
our methodology and thinking you know this does aws make sense for us or not
so we started that process by a cost analysis and essentially we were going from on-premise to aws so we had
existing infrastructure we had a number of servers storage you know racks everything else that goes with your
on-premise infrastructure so we came up with an inventory of what that is quantities versus specs
and then we pulled up the aws calculator and did a comparison with what we have versus what similar capacity aws
provides but part of that that uh cost analysis is not just servers to servers there's a
lot more that makes up your on-premise infrastructure there's load balancers there's storage there's the
environmentals power and cooling this rack space and there's also the support and maintenance contracts that support
all this hardware so all this quickly adds up from a cost perspective
so what we notice is that if you were to take just your servers
and compare them to the ec2 equivalent instances in aws
we saw like a 35 savings average but then when we also included our load
balancer storage and everything else rackspace it was more like 50
so it quickly became pretty compelling for us that at least strictly from an economics perspective aws makes sense
we also came up we also realized two two real outcomes one
we don't have the scale i mean we're not small but we're not at aws size
so we don't have the ability to compete with aws on price we just there's just no way we can do it
but more importantly we also can compete on speed and by that i mean if my
internal customer comes to me and says hey we need this application deployed and we need the infrastructure for it
traditionally in the past i would have to involve procurement the vendor our ops teams that entire
process takes four to six weeks now in aws we can do that in minutes to hours
so that difference in time provides a really compelling and competitive
advantage that you know in in this industry every every day counts
so now i'm going to walk you through the various use cases that we leverage aws for in the in the autodesk consumer
group pretty much all of our production workloads all the apps that i talked about in the beginning they all run on
aws be it mobile desktop or web also all our dev test environments run
in aws all when net new systems run in aws so it's safe to assume that we're all in on
aws so why did we decide to choose splunk
for to enable or manage our aws adoption well we had splunk prior to going to aws
so it was an existing existing investment that we had it was familiar technology
our engineers are comfortable with splunk within within our group
splunk is typically synonymous with logging anything that has to be logged splunk is a de facto application that we
go to and also the splunk app for aws really easily enables you to manage
multiple accounts centrally and that's something that we have that's uh i won't say a problem but we are set up in such
a way that we do have a lot of aws accounts
so for us to be able to show or use splunk to provide assurances
for aws adoptions we need to be able to address operations security as well as
business intelligence on the operations side we're collecting data from thousands of endpoints all
over the world that's where splunk app for aws really makes that really easy to do centrally
from a security perspective our security team needs to be able to react quickly to any incidents that
happen in our infrastructure they need to be able to have all the data at hand and the splunk app for enterprise
security enables that for us on the business intelligence side we create custom dashboards
that our product teams and executives use on a daily to weekly basis to be
able to see how you as potential customers or us customers are using our software
how where our software is being downloaded how many active users we have what's the ratio of mobile to web and
i'll show you some screenshots of that later as well so now i'm going to go into a
few minutes of screenshots that show how we're using splunk to enable
that aws adoption so the first one is the cloudtrail dashboard and with this
dashboard we can quickly see where or what our error rates are for
how our apps are in or are using the aws apis we can also see for each
uh for each um aws service like sqs iam ec2
how many api calls we're making to them and how that's trending over the past 24 hours we can also see where in the world
those calls are coming from on the business intelligence side these
are the custom dashboards that we have generated so here we can see for this particular product the amount of active
users we have how many new subscribers how many renewals mobile versus web
usage we can also see for our ap for internal api calls what are the latencies for each
and then for some of our products we have assets that you generate and then upload to the to the platform we can see
how many are created day over day hour over hour on a security front this is where things
get kind of cool and interesting we can answer questions that we couldn't before for example in in this particular case
we had a we had a potential breach in an account in a certain time window that we
knew the breach happened we were able to run a query that was able to tell us
within that time window what are the events that occurred and then we by getting that list we can now see if
those events were actually malicious or not but we can go back in time you know
as far back as we need to to be able to do that retroactively or you know as it's happening right now
then we're also able to answer questions like we we know this particular host is compromised we want to know what this
host has done in our infrastructure so we take that ip address and we leverage
the uh the cloudtrail data plug that into splunk and here for example when we when we issue that query we can see that
this particular instance was used to describe our other infrastructure so
based on that information we could then see okay was that a threat or was that not a threat but this is all vital data
that was security team needs to be able to to to see and react on on a
fairly quickly quick basis also this particular use case is fairly common where you have an iem key
and since i mentioned we have a number of aws accounts you have no way of knowing which account it's for and what
are the permissions behind it with cloudtrail and splunk you can plug in that iem key and it will tell you
what account is what account that imt was issued from and also what that im
key was used for in this case we can see that it was used to create an sqsq and
it was used to describe health checks for elb and ec2
and then lastly we can also visualize where our employees are accessing the aws console
for so in this case we'll be we can see authorized versus unauthorized access on
a global basis to the aws console for all our accounts
now i'm going to spend some time talking about how we operationalize running splunk in aws so you have splunk you
want to move it to aws this is how for us to be able to run splunk in aws
we needed to be able to achieve at least three tenets we had to be able to have we needed automation we needed
scalability and we needed performance for automation we developed and
outsourced uh two github repository repositories one it has that contains a
cloud formation template that cloudformation template builds the base infrastructure for your for your your
splunk cluster so it builds the servers it provisions of storage the elbs load balancers the vpcs as well
and i'll show you in the next slide in more detail what that does and then once that base infrastructure is provisioned
then the other repository contains the ansible playbook that ansible playbook downloads splunk installs splunk
configures splunk and then configures each component of the splunk cluster so
the search heads the pair nodes the supporting cluster master license master each one
as well as security each one that playbook configures for you so basically
you can run splunk or you can run a brand new splunk deployment in under 20
minutes without really knowing needing to know how to install splunk itself
from a scalability perspective we need to be able to add and remove nodes quickly
so for example search heads a user could potentially run an ad hoc query that consumes all the cpu
utilization on one maybe even two search heads that then will will yield a negative
user experience to another user by leveraging auto scaling groups we can set up policies that say once cpu
utilization hits 80 percent provision one or two more nodes
and then when c when average cpu goes back down so let's say 40 then deprovision nodes so that makes the
system very resilient and we don't need to have somebody there that's constantly
monitoring and reacting it basically handles itself then i mentioned search head pooling but
such pooling is a feature that we leverage today for scalability that basically allows you to have a shared
nfs share or you know data store that can be accessed by multiple search heads in the
latest version of splunk splunk62 they've deprecated search head pooling
so it's no longer needed and that's something that we're going to be doing uh pretty soon um
so i just mentioned it for historical purposes and in performance performance is key right if you have your splunk cluster
and it takes minutes to run your searches your users are not going to be happy so you want to be as fast as
possible and what we found in our tests is that the c3 instance family is a good
fit for search heads because they tend to be very cpu intensive and then for indexers we have a few more
options so depending on the size of the cluster that we're building if it's a dev test cluster that we're just like
testing a new feature or testing a new data source we want a small data set so for those we typically go with c3
instance c3 ec2 instances plus ebs but for our larger production clusters
that's where we really leverage i2 instances with a local ephemeral storage
hs1 instances are also a a good uh option as well and then to maximize your
iops you want to rate zero all your your disk volumes
so this is the typical infrastructure splunk infrastructure that we build and the confirmation template and ansible
playbooks this is essentially what they will build for you so the very top we leverage direct
connect to bridge our corporate network to the vpc where aws where splunk is
running we have our elb at the very top and then that talks the fleet of search heads
which then talks a fleet of peer nodes and then we have the supporting infrastructure on on the side and as you
can see everything is in auto scaling group
so now i'm going to talk about how we use cloudtrail plus splunk together what our typical configuration is to be
able to manage a large number of accounts centrally
so for this example account a and account b it's you know let's let's take that to be you know one product versus
another product but then we also have a third account called the core services account and that account typically hosts
any infrastructure that's common across the vast majority of our accounts like dns monitoring splunk
so we enable cloudtrail in each of the the linked accounts and we configure
cloudtrail to send its events to the central s3 bucket in the core services account and now all this can be
done either via the aws cli or the aws console cloudtrail also sends its events via an
sns notification topic that then sends its messages to
a central sqsq in the core services account splunk then pulls sqsq and the messages
in that sqsq can contain the url of where that event is located in s3 so splunk just has to
look at that message and it knows where in s3 to pull in the logs
we found this we've found this deployment to be really simple to configure because all the components are
very decoupled it's also very scalable and it it enables our
our need to have one central location for all that data
so in summary i talked about how aws and splunk is really for us an ideal couple
how we leverage cloudtrail and splunk in a scalable in a scalable
configuration that uh that works very well across hundreds of accounts
and additionally how we use our various use cases for splunk that are leveraged by
our operations security and business teams
